themes.title: Exploring Chinese Porcelain
points: Introduce porcelain as a shiny, smooth material that feels cool to the touch—perfect for engaging young students with sensory descriptions.
Explain how porcelain was made by heating special clay at very high temperatures—compare it to baking cookies in an oven to make it relatable.
Highlight the cultural importance of porcelain in China, calling it 'China's treasure' and linking it to the students' interest in art and curiosities.

themes.title: Symbolism in Art
points: Point out the ducks and lotus flowers on Jiajing period porcelain—explain that ducks symbolize love and lotus flowers symbolize purity in Chinese culture.
Ask students to imagine what symbols they would use to represent their own feelings or ideas, tying it back to their art class.
Relate symbolism to psychology by discussing how people use images to express emotions or tell stories.

themes.title: Time Travel Through Dynasties
points: Introduce the Yuan dynasty mallet-shaped vases and explain their journey to Japan—describe how objects can travel just like people do.
Discuss the Kangxi and Daoguang periods, explaining that each dynasty had its own unique style of porcelain—compare it to how kids might decorate their art projects differently.
Use a timeline to show the progression of porcelain styles, helping students visualize the changes over time.

themes.title: Hands-On Engagement
points: Ask students to imagine holding a mallet-shaped vase—what do they think it would feel like? Heavy or light? Smooth or rough?
Invite students to identify colors and patterns on the porcelain pieces, encouraging them to describe what they see.
Have students draw their own vase or plate, using symbols like ducks or flowers to tell a story—connect this activity to their art class.

themes.title: Curiosities and Fun Facts
points: Share the fun fact that porcelain was so special it was traded across countries—compare it to trading toys or stickers.
Explain that Longquan celadon is a greenish glaze that looks like jade—ask students if they've ever seen something green and shiny like it.
Mention that each porcelain piece in the exhibit is hundreds of years old—ask students to guess what life was like when these objects were made.
